Overview  The Government of India (Government) recognizes electricity as 
one of the key drivers for economic growth and poverty reduction 
and  has  confirmed  its  mission  to  provide  electricity  to  all 
households at an affordable price by 2012. This policy, Power for 
All by 2012, will require additional generation capacity of 78,600 
megawatts  (MW)  during  the  period  of  the  11th  Five-Year  Plan 
(FY2008–FY2012).  
The Integrated Energy Policy (IEP) adopted by the Government in 
2006 specifies certain regulatory measures for (i) optimizing the 
power supply mix through greater use of indigenous hydropower 
resources and renewable energy, (ii) pursuing technologies that 
maximize energy efficiency, and (iii) continuing the ongoing power 
reforms to control technical and commercial losses. In particular, 
the IEP aims to change the current hydro-thermal energy ratio of 
25:75 to 40:60, with the renewable energy input to constitute not 
less than 10% of the generation base by 2012. The nationwide 
energy efficiency potential (including cogeneration) is estimated at 
over 20,000 MW, but the realization of this potential will require 
robust regulatory incentives on behalf of the Government.  
 
The Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) energy sector program 
for  India  aims  at  enhancing  the  impact  of  the  Government’s 
initiatives  and  includes  both  demand-  and  supply-related 
programs.  The  planned  activities  include  (i)  renovation  and 
modernization of existing hydropower and thermal power plants, 
(ii) upgrade of inefficient thermal power plants to enhance their 
performance,  (iii)  development  of  renewable  and  alternative 
energy sources, (iv) reduction of technical and commercial losses 
in transmission and distribution networks and facilities, and (v) 
bringing demand-side management and energy conservation into 
the  mainstream  while  ensuring  environmental  and  social 
sustainability. The recently launched ADB Carbon Market Initiative
and Energy Efficiency Initiative will leverage additional resources

ii   
to  accelerate  the  promotion  of  energy  efficiency,  renewable 
energy, and  other  forms of clean energy in India. As natural 
energy resources are unevenly distributed and often located far 
from  the  load  centers,  the  additional  generation  capacity  will 
require the development of an adequate intrastate and interstate 
transmission  system  to  ensure  reliable  and  secure  delivery  of 
power from generation plants to end users. The Central Electricity 
Authority (CEA) has developed the National Electricity Plan, and 
this is to be used as a basis of investment plans to be prepared by 
prospective  generating  companies  and  transmission  and 
distribution licensees at the central and state level. 
   
Power Transmission Sector. The Indian power system is divided 
into  five  regions—northern,  southern,  western,  eastern,  and 
northeastern. Except for the eastern and northeastern regions, all 
the regions are presently facing power shortages in the range of 
about  300–6,000  MW.  Considering  the  generation  addition 
program  up  to  FY2012,  the  maximum  surplus  power  in  the 
eastern region is expected to be around 12,000 MW and in the 
northeastern  region  around  3,000  MW;  however,  the  northern, 
western, and southern regions will need to import power to a large 
extent from the northeastern and eastern regions to reduce their 
deficit situation.  Therefore,  development  of  strong  interregional 
links connecting the northeastern and eastern regions to all other 
regions is needed.  
 
While the state governments are responsible for the intrastate 
transmission system, the Government is focusing on the creation 
of a national grid in a phased manner by adding over 60,000 
circuit kilometers (ckm) of transmission network by 2012. This will 
enable the integrated grid to transmit an additional 78,600 MW 
and carry 60% of the power generated in the country, increasing 
interregional power transfer capacity from 14,100 MW in March 
2007  to  more  than  37,000  MW.  For  this  purpose,  capital 
investment of about $18.75 billion will be required during the 11th 
Five-Year  Plan  to  (i)  strengthen  regional  grids,  (ii)  increase 
interregional capacity, and (iii) establish a unified load dispatch 
scheme. 
 
Power Grid Corporation of India Ltd. Power Grid Corporation of 
India Ltd (POWERGRID), the central transmission utility tasked 
with  developing,  operating,  and  maintaining  the  national 
transmission grid, will be responsible for investing $13.75 billion 
during the plan period. The balance of $5 billion is expected from 
the  private  sector.  To  achieve  its  mission,  POWERGRID  has 
developed  a  long-term  corporate  strategic  plan  for  the  period 
2003–2012.  The  strategy  covers  various  areas  including  (i) 
contract management, (ii) project implementation and monitoring, 
(iii)  operation  and  maintenance,  (iv)  environmental  and  social 
safeguards,  (v)  corporate  governance,  (vi)  technology 
development,  (vi)  information  technology,  (vii)  human  resource

iii
management, (viii) cost reduction, (ix) fund mobilization, and (x) 
business process reengineering. While POWERGRID already has 
sufficient institutional capacity to implement the strategy, it has 
been  implementing  capacity-development  initiatives  including 
training programs for executives, managers, and line workers in 
specialized areas.  The  capacity-development  program  is  being 
financed through internal resources. 
 
Sector Road Map and  Policy  Environment.  The  Electricity  Act  2003  provides  a 
Investment Program  complete legal framework for implementing the reforms, including 
Description  (i)  the  unbundling  of  state  electricity  boards  (SEBs),  (ii)  the 
establishment  of  state  regulators,  (iii)  licensing,  and  (iv)  an 
antitheft  provision.  So  far,  23  state  electricity  regulatory 
commissions  have  been  constituted  and  16  states  have 
unbundled and or corporatized their SEBs. The Electricity Act also 
represents a departure from the previous regime of the power 
sector by introducing more competition into the wholesale market 
in addition to retail markets. Certain provisions in the Electricity 
Act, such as (i) open access to the transmission and distribution 
network, (ii) recognition of power trading as a distinct activity, and 
(iii) the liberal definition of a captive generating plant, have already 
started  to  introduce  and  encourage  competition  in  the  power 
sector. Under the Electricity Act, 18 states have issued open-
access guidelines. 
 
Transmission Sector Road Map. The 11th Five-Year Plan aims 
to further accelerate the reforms and underpins the Government’s 
mission  of  Power  for  All  by  2012  through  (i)  expanding  the 
coverage,  (ii)  improving  the  reliability,  and  (iii)  enhancing  the 
sustainability and efficiency of the interstate transmission network. 
Expected outcomes and major milestones of the plan are defined 
in  the  transmission  sector  road  map.  The  sector  road  map 
includes specific technical targets to be achieved by 2012 in terms 
of  expansion  of  the  national  power  grid  and  reliability  and 
efficiency of the grid operations. As POWERGRID is the primary 
provider of interstate and interregional transmission services, the 
sector road map also includes various measures based on its 
long-term corporate strategy to further strengthen POWERGRID’s 
institutional  capacity  to  achieve  the  technical  targets.  These 
measures  aim  to  strengthen  corporate  governance,  improve 
efficiencies,  and  enhance  financial  viability  of  POWERGRID 
through (i) financial management, (ii) safeguard compliance, (iii) 
human resource management, (iv) information technology, and (v) 
cost reduction. 
 
Investment Program. The proposed investment program is part 
of the $13.75 billion investment plan of POWERGRID and will 
primarily  have  two  projects  for  ADB  funding.  Project  1 
(Upgradation  of  Transmission  Capacity  from  Uttarakhand)  will 
provide transmission arrangement for the evacuation and reliable 
transfer of hydropower generated in the Tehri Valley in the state of

iv   
Uttarakhand to the northern region. Project 2 (±800 kilovolt [kV] 
High  Voltage  Direct  Current  [HVDC]  Northeastern–
Northern/Western  Interconnector)  aims  to  deliver  bulk  power 
generated from hydropower stations in the northeastern region to 
the power-deficit areas of the northern and western regions. Other 
projects may be added, if necessary. 
 
  The investment program is estimated to cost the equivalent of 
about $2.542 billion including taxes, duties, and interest and other 
charges  on  the  loans  during  construction.  POWERGRID  has 
requested financing of up to the equivalent of $600 million from 
ADB’s ordinary capital resources under the sovereign-guaranteed 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF).  POWERGRID  has  also 
requested a $400 million nonsovereign loan.  
 
Clean Energy and Energy Efficiency. Projects 1 and 2 under 
the proposed investment program will improve the overall power 
system  efficiency  in  the  northern  and  western  regions  by 
establishing adequate high-efficiency transmission infrastructure 
with a planned transmission capacity enhancement of 4,500 MW. 
The  efficiency  improvements  will  result  from  upgrading  the 
transmission network in Uttarakhand and the use of ±800 HVDC 
technology for transmission of bulk power over a long distance 
(1,800 kilometers [km]) within the northeastern–northern/western 
interconnecting corridor.  
 
The  huge  advantage  of  the  HVDC  technology  is  its  ability  to 
transmit large amounts of power over long distances with much 
lower  technical  losses  than  alternating  current  (AC)  systems. 
Losses in HVDC lines are quoted at as low as 3% per 1,000 km. 
By  2012,  upon  the  completion  of  two  associated  hydropower 
facilities with a combined capacity of 2,600 MW, the reduction in 
transmission  losses  alone  will  bring  about  228  gigawatt-hours 
(GWh)  of  clean  electricity  transmitted  annually  through  the 
northeastern–northern/western interconnecting corridor. In 2015, 
when extra hydropower capacity of 3,000 MW comes online, the 
reduced transmission losses will result in 491 GWh of additional 
electrical energy per year. In addition, the planned HVDC link will 
not only transmit excess electricity from the northeastern grid to 
the capacity-deficient northern and western grids, but also make 
possible the realization of supply-side energy efficiency, which is 
not  achievable  in  the  case  of  conventional  AC  transmission 
systems.  The  efficiency  gains  come  from  the  ability  of  HVDC 
systems to allow a quick change in the direction of power flow 
(bidirectionality).  This  will  permit  (i)  the  meeting  of  peak-load 
needs and provision of emergency power into the northern and 
western  grids  when  fossil-fuel  plants  go  offline  unexpectedly 
(peak-shaving  load  management),  and  (ii)  storage  of  off-peak 
power from thermal facilities which are not easily cycled (valley-
filling load management).

v
The proposed investment program also will generate substantial 
environmental  benefits relating  to  the  reduction  of  greenhouse 
gases  and  other  pollutants.  The  projects  planned  under  the 
investment program will allow avoiding the expansion of thermal 
power generation in the Northern and Western regions through 
enabling the transmission of hydropower from the Northeastern 
region of India. ADB estimates that hydropower plants associated 
with Project 1 will offset more than 263 million tons (t) of CO  
2
equivalent,  and  with  Project  2  the  figure  is  551  million  t. 
Furthermore, additional cumulative offsets gained from reduced 
transmission losses will account for 7 million (t) of CO  equivalent 
2
over the lifetime of the project. 
 
Multitranche Financing  The financing will be provided under the MFF, in accordance with 
Facility  ADB policy.1 The MFF will extend multiple loans of no less than 
$100  million  to  finance  part  of  the  costs  of  the  two  projects 
constituting the investment program. Additional projects may be 
added if necessary. These will be subject to submission of related 
periodic financing requests (PFRs) by POWERGRID and India, 
and execution of the related loan and guarantee agreements.  
 
The  provisions  of  the  ordinary  operations  loan  regulations 
applicable to ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based 
lending facility will apply to each loan, subject to modifications, if 
any,  that  might  be  included  under  each  loan  agreement.  The 
specific terms of each loan will be based on the related PFR, with 
interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-based 
lending facility.  
 
Rationale  The investment program will (i) provide long-term and predictable 
financing for POWERGRID’s huge investment requirements; (ii) 
reduce 821 million t of carbon dioxide (CO )-equivalent emissions 
2
over the lifetime of two proposed projects primarily by replacing 
thermal  generation  at  the  demand  site  with  transmitted,  clean 
hydropower;  (iii)  help  POWERGRID  implement  its  capacity-
development program under the corporate strategic plan; (iv) help 
POWERGRID  prepare  for  external  commercial  borrowing  to 
broaden and deepen its access to financial markets; (v) introduce 
best  practices,  such  as  state-of-the-art  HVDC  transmission 
technologies;  and  (vi)  ensure  sound  environmental  and  social 
safeguard policies are followed. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The investment program is expected to promote sustained social 
and  economic  prosperity  and  growth  in  India  by  providing 
adequate  and  reliable  power  supply.  Inadequate  supply  of 
electricity has been a major hindrance to economic growth in the 
country, affecting all consumer groups and social classes.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche financing facility (the Facility) to Power Grid Corporation of India Ltd (POWERGRID), 
guaranteed by India, for the National Power Grid Development Investment Program. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Sector Overview 
 
2.  Balanced infrastructure development is a major challenge for India to overcome if it is to 
achieve its sustainable economic growth target of 8–9% annually over the next 25 years. Given 
infrastructure inadequacies now exist in both rural and urban areas, preliminary exercises by the 
Government of India indicate that investment in infrastructure will need to increase from 4.6% of 
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  to  between  7%  and  8%  in  the  11th  Five-Year  Plan  period. 
Development needs in the power sector are vast; India’s need for power is growing rapidly with 
consumption increasing by about 64% over the last 10 years. The forecast growth in electricity 
demand to support a GDP growth rate of about 9% is expected to be 8%. This is higher than the 
last 10 years, as the energy-intensive manufacturing sector is expected to increase its share of 
GDP. However, electricity is still inaccessible to the majority of households. While over 80% of 
villages are already electrified, only 44% of total households have access to electricity, and in the 
rural areas only 33% of households have access to electricity. As of 31 March 2005, per capita 
electricity consumption stood at about 606 kilowatt-hours (kWh) annually.  
  
3.  Energy  and  peaking  shortage  are  high,  with  frequent  load  shedding  (rationing)  and 
significant  voltage  fluctuation  at  metered  consumer  levels.  This  undermines  industrial 
competitiveness and severely constrains economic growth. The major reasons for inadequate, 
erratic,  and  unreliable  power  supply  especially  at  the    state  level  are  (i)  inadequate  power 
generation capacity, (ii) lack of optimum utilization of the existing generation capacity, (iii) an 
inadequate and aging subtransmission and distribution network, (iv) large scale theft and a skewed 
tariff structure, (v) slow pace of rural electrification, and (vi) inefficient use of electricity by the end 
consumer. 
 
4.  In India, aggregate technical and commercial [AT&C] losses are quite high arising mainly 
from distribution losses, unmetered connections, theft, and subsidies to agricultural consumers. 
Nationwide AT&C losses amount to as much as 40%, compared to the world average of 10–15%, 
while some states such as Madhya Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh and Gujarat have shown remarkable 
improvement in reducing AT&C losses. The operational inefficiencies represented by such high 
AT&C losses, combined with retail tariffs set far below the cost of supply, have resulted in a 
deterioration of the financial health of state electricity boards (SEBs). Despite the Government’s 
efforts to create enabling and encouraging policy and regulatory framework, poor creditworthiness 
of SEB remains a major hindrance to private sector investment in some states.  
 
5.  In  line  with  the  Electricity  Regulatory  Commission  Act  1998,  the  Central  Electricity 
Regulatory Commission (CERC) was established in 1998, and has full authority to determine bulk 
tariffs. The 1998 act enables state governments to establish state electricity regulatory commissions 
with jurisdiction over state power utilities. CERC regulates interstate, regional, and interregional 
transmission, while the 23 state electricity regulatory commissions regulate state transmission and

2   
distribution. State and central regulatory commissions have powers to (i) grant, amend, and revoke 
licenses; (ii) regulate the performance of licensees; (iii) determine tariffs; (iv) safeguard consumers' 
interests while ensuring cost recovery of electricity; (v) promote development of markets, including 
trading; and (vi) rationalize electricity tariffs by making subsidies transparent. 
 
6.  To further accelerate the sector reforms, the Government enacted the Electricity Act 2003, 
which came into force in June 2003. The Electricity Act provides for a complete legal framework for 
implementing the reforms, including (i) the unbundling of SEBs, (ii) establishment of the state 
regulator, (iii) licensing, and (iv) an anti-theft provision. The Act also represents a departure from 
the previous power sector regime by introducing more competition into wholesale as well as retail 
markets. Certain provisions in the Electricity Act, such as (i) open access to the transmission and 
distribution  network,  (ii)  recognition  of  power  trading  as  a  distinct  activity,  and  (iii)  the  liberal 
definition of a captive generating plant, are expected to introduce and encourage competition in the 
power sector. Under the Electricity Act, 18 states have issued open-access guidelines. 
 
  2.  Sector Strategy and Policy 
 
7.  Cognizant of the pivotal role the power sector plays in development for economic growth 
and  poverty  reduction,  the  Government  has  confirmed  its  mission  to  provide  electricity  to  all 
households at an affordable price by 2012. This goal of Power for All by 2012 has been elaborated 
into subsector-specific policies in the National Electricity Policy, which was prepared in February 
2005 in accordance with the Electricity Act 2003. The Government has set ambitious energy policy 
objectives to achieve annual generation capacity of 1,000 kWh per capita by 2012. The magnitude 
of investment needed to achieve this goal is vast. Net capacity addition of 78,600 megawatts (MW) 
will be required under the 11th Five-Year Plan period.  
 8.  Integrated Energy Policy. The Integrated Energy Policy (IEP) adopted by the Government 
in 2006 specifies certain regulatory measures for (i) optimizing the power supply mix through 
greater use of indigenous hydropower resources and renewable energy, (ii) pursuing technologies 
that maximize energy efficiency, and (iii) continuing the ongoing power reforms to control technical 
and commercial losses. The Government is endeavoring to turn the IEP targets into tangible 
outcomes through the provision of incentives for investors in order to overcome such challenges as 
(i) the perceived advantages of capital investment in everyday technology, (ii) smaller project sizes 
resulting  in  higher  transaction  costs  of  project  preparation,  and  (iii)  the  lack  of  institutional 
capacities. In particular, the IEP aims to change the hydro-thermal energy ratio from the current 
25:75 to 40:60, with the renewable energy input to constitute not less than 10% of the generation 
base, by 2012. The nationwide energy efficiency potential (including cogeneration) is estimated at 
over 20,000 MW, but the realization of this potential will require robust regulatory incentives from 
the Government.  
    
9.  Generation. Coal fuel will continue to dominate power production in India in the near future, 
as the country attempts to increase its generation capacity to keep up with growing industrial and 
residential power demand. India will continue to emphasize the development of large-scale pithead 
coal-fired plants to take advantage of domestic coal resources rather than increase fossil-fuel 
energy imports. However, the Government is endeavoring to minimize environmental impacts by 
using state-of-the-art technologies and continuing the development of clean and renewable sources 
of energy such as the untapped hydropower potential in the northeastern and northern regions.  
10.  The thermal-hydro ratio was close to 50:50 in the early 1960s, partly because the early 
economic development policy emphasized support for agriculture, which has extensive irrigation 
demands. Industrial development became a priority in the 1960s, when new thermal plants became 
dominant. By 2003, for a variety of reasons, the Government recognized the need to increase the

3  
hydropower proportion and introduced an initiative to develop up to about 50,000 MW of new 
hydropower capacity as part of the Power for All by 2012 policy. The Ministry of Power (MOP) 
conducted preliminary feasibility studies on about 300 candidate sites, and identified over 30,000 
MW of potential hydropower that could be commercially developed (based on an estimated 1st-year 
tariff of Rs. 2 per kWh or less). MOP has implemented several policy measures to accelerate 
hydropower development, including the streamlining of the project approval process and a review of 
tariff policies.  
11.  Transmission. As natural energy resources are unevenly distributed and often located far 
from the load centers, additional generation capacity will require development of an adequate 
intrastate and interstate transmission system to ensure reliable and secure delivery of power. The 
Central Electricity Authority (CEA) has developed the National Electricity Plan, which is to be used 
as  a  basis  for  investment  plans  to  be  prepared  by  prospective  generating  companies  and 
transmission  and  distribution  licensees  at  the  central  and  state  level.  In  line  with  the  plan, 
POWERGRID is tasked to develop the national power grid to provide adequate infrastructure for 
interstate transmission of power so as to ensure that underutilized generation capacity is used and 
the power is transmitted to deficit regions. The transmission sector can play a pivotal role in 
implementing the IEP by (i) ensuring regional energy security with a transnational grid, enabling the 
region to avoid overdependence on fossil-fuel energy resources; (ii) reducing greenhouse gas 
emissions by connecting hydropower and renewable energy power plants to the load centers; and 
(iii) enhancing energy efficiency through technical loss reduction using advanced technologies.  
 
12.  Distribution. The major weakness of the power sector is on the distribution side, which is 
entirely  the  domain  of  the  states.  Restoring  the  financial  viability  of  the  sector  through  the 
restructure of the state utilities (while still safeguarding consumer interests) is a major challenge. 
Consequently, the Accelerated Power Development and Reform Program (APDRP) was initiated in 
2001 to introduce reforms at the distribution level with an overall objective of reducing AT&C losses 
to 15% by 2007. While metering on 11 kilovolt (kV) feeders has improved from 81% in 2001 to 96% 
in 2006, and consumer metering has improved from 78% to 92% in the same period, average 
AT&C losses are still close to 50%, which the Government aims to reduce to 15% by the end of the 
11th Five-Year Plan period. In addition to financial support under the APDRP, many states have 
unbundled  their  SEBs  to  put  distribution  companies  under  regulatory  oversight  for  efficiency 
improvements.  The  Government  encourages  private  sector  participation  in  distribution  through 
privatization and franchising. 
 
  3.  Power Grid Corporation of India, Limited 
 
13.  POWERGRID was established in October 1989 and became fully operational in 1992. It is 
responsible  for  developing,  operating,  and  maintaining  the  national  transmission  grid,  which 
includes  interstate  and  interregional  transmission  lines.  Prior  to  its  formation,  central  sector 
generating companies constructed and operated their own transmission facilities to supply and 
distribute power from their power plants. As a result, the national transmission system has evolved 
in a rather haphazard manner, resulting in transmission bottlenecks in many areas; most regions 
are not fully synchronized with each other and there are limited transfers of power. 
 
14.  As of December 2007, POWERGRID operates and maintains one of the largest extra-high 
voltage transmission networks in the world, with about 65,000 circuit kilometers (ckm) of extra-high 
voltage lines, along with 110 substations with transmission capacity of about 66,000 megavolt-
amperes (MVA) and carries about 45% of generated power across the country through its national 
transmission grid. The national grid has an interregional capacity of 17,000 MW as of December 
2007, which is planned to be increased to more than 37,000 MW by the end of 2012. POWERGRID

4   
owns and operates five state-of-the-art regional load dispatch centers and is implementing the 
National Load Dispatch Center to integrate them. 
 
15.  POWERGRID has achieved remarkable growth since it started commercial operations in 
1992 and has demonstrated high productivity among major transmission companies in the world. Its 
system availability was above 99% in FY2007 and technical loss level is reported at 3–4%, which is 
comparable with international standards. POWERGRID played a major role in implementing the 
availability-based tariffs in the country, which helped stabilize vital grid parameters such as voltage 
and frequency to prevent tripping. POWERGRID has also invested in modernizing regional load 
dispatch  centers,  which  has  also  improved  operating  efficiency  of  the  transmission  system. 
POWERGRID has developed into a well-respected public sector enterprise, which attracts highly 
qualified staff who are employing international standards of design, engineering, construction, and 
operations. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Key Challenges and Opportunities of the Power Transmission Sector 
 
16.  Prior  to  1992  when  POWERGRID  became  fully  operational,  central  sector  generating 
companies constructed and operated the transmission facilities to distribute power from their power 
plants and transmit it to client SEBs. At that time, the generation and transmission system in the 
country  was  planned  and  developed  on  the  basis  of  regional  self-sufficiency.  Interregional 
transmission arrangements were envisaged only for transfer of intermittent operational surpluses of 
small magnitude. With the formation of strong regional grid systems, the focus was shifted to 
planning on an all-India basis and for a free flow of electricity across the whole country through a 
strong national power grid. 
 
17.  The Indian power system is divided into five electrical regions—northern, southern, western, 
eastern, and northeastern. Except for the eastern and northeastern regions, all the regions are 
presently facing power shortages in the range of about 300–6,000 MW. Considering the generation 
addition program up to FY2012, the maximum surplus power in the eastern region is expected to be 
in  the  range  of  12,000  MW  and  in  the  northeastern  region  around  3,000  MW;  however,  the 
northern, western, and southern regions will need to import power to a large extent from the 
northeastern and eastern regions to alleviate their deficits.  
 
18.  The transmission sector has a great opportunity to enhance energy efficiency and minimize 
environmental  impacts,  as  well  as  improve  regional  energy  security,  by  developing  advanced 
national and transnational grids with cutting-edge technologies such as high voltage direct current 
(HVDC) for connecting the load centers to hydropower and renewable energy power plants in India 
and neighboring countries. State-of-the-art technology will be needed to transfer power with minimal 
losses and under right-of-way constraints from the resource-rich northeastern and eastern regions 
to distant load centers in the northern and western regions.  
 
  2.  Sector Investment and Financing Plan 
 
19.  The development agenda for the transmission sector is twofold. At the state level, where 
SEBs are responsible, strengthening and modernization of the intrastate transmission system is 
immediately needed to reduce technical losses and enhance reliability of state grids. At the central 
level, where POWERGRID is the  primary provider of transmission service, transmission capacity 
expansion between states and regions is a major challenge for optimizing the use of the country’s 
energy resources, and one which will require enormous investment. According to the least-cost

5  
generation expansion program and demand projection for different regions, the northeastern and 
eastern region will be the major power exporter for other regions. Therefore, development of strong 
interregional links interconnecting the northeastern and eastern regions to all other regions are 
needed. By 2012, the eastern, western, and northern regions will be interconnected by a high 
capacity 765 kV ring, while the southern region will remain interconnected in asynchronous mode. 
The northeastern region is also expected to be connected with the eastern region by a high-
capacity 400kV alternating current (AC) link and with the northern and western regions by a high-
capacity 800kV high voltage direct current (HVDC) link. This will constitute a stronger national 
power grid with high-capacity transmission. 
 
20.  At the central level, the Government, therefore, is focusing on the creation of a national grid 
in a phased manner by adding over 60,000 ckm of transmission network by 2012 so that the 
integrated grid can handle an additional 78,600 MW and carry 60% of the power generated in the 
country, increasing interregional power transfer capacity from 14,100 MW in March 2007 to more 
than 37,000 MW. For this purpose, capital investment of about $18.75 billion will be required during 
the 11th Five-Year Plan period to (i) strengthen regional grids, (ii) increase interregional capacity, 
and (iii) establish a unified load dispatch scheme. Out of this, investment of $13.75 billion will be 
made  by  POWERGRID  for  its  own  facilities  and  the  balance  of  $5  billion  will  be  mainly  for 
generation-linked transmission projects to be constructed and owned either privately or through 
public-private partnership. POWERGRID may participate in the projects jointly with private sector

21.  Private Sector Participation. The Government amended Indian Electricity Laws to enable 
private sector participation in transmission sector. In January 2000, the Government issued detailed 
guidelines. The guidelines envisage two routes for inviting private sector investment. One route is 
through joint venture of central transmission utility / state transmission utility and private sector.  
The first joint venture has been established by POWERGRID and Tata Power Company Ltd for 
1,200 km of transmission lines associated with the Tala Hydro Electric Power in Bhutan on Build-
Own-Operate Transfer basis. The project was successfully commissioned in August 2006. ADB

at an advanced stage of selection of investors. The other option is through what is known as an 
independent private transmission company, and this envisages 100% private-sector investment. 
Part of a system strengthening project in the western region is being implemented in this way. 
POWERGRID plans various joint-venture projects between now and 2012. 
 
22.  Corporate  Governance.  POWERGRID  is  committed  to  sound  corporate  governance 
principles by promoting corporate fairness, transparency, fiduciary responsibility, and accountability 
amongst  all  its  stakeholders,  beyond  its  sole  shareholder.  POWERGRID  believes  that  good 
governance should entail trusteeship, empowerment, and accountability of the management while 
remaining responsive to Government policies. It is focused towards its mission of “establishment 
and operation of regional and national power grids to facilitate transfer of power within and across 
the regions with reliability, security and economy on sound commercial principles.”2 This mission is 
carried out based on the well-established practices in engineering and design, procurement, project 
management, finance, and human resources, which are being followed in letter and spirit and are 
being continually improved upon. 
 
23.   Because its bonds are publicly listed, POWERGRID is required by the Securities and 
Exchange Board of India to have at least 50% of its board directors as nonexecutive members. 
Presently, POWERGRID has nine directors — three executive directors from POWERGRID and six 
nonexecutive directors. Of the six nonexecutive directors, two are government directors appointed 
part-time; the other four are independent directors.  
 
24.  To introduce a further layer of nonexecutive oversight into its corporate governance system, 
POWERGRID has introduced certain committees of independent eminent persons relating to the 
following  areas:  (i)  financial  management,  (ii)  procurement,  (iii)  environmental  and  social 
safeguards, and (iv) research and development. These committees report directly to the chairman. 
In order to have better and more focused attention on certain areas, the board has also constituted 
several other subcommittees to focus on functional matters such as (i) the award of contracts, (ii) 
feasibility reports and revised cost estimates, and (iii) bonds. Improvements suggested by the 
experts are progressively incorporated into POWERGRID’s procedures. POWERGRID is committed 
to effective quality project management aligned to its documented quality management system to 
the requirements of International Organization for Standardization (lSO) 9001 1994 (certification 
achieved in July 1995). An integrated management system has been developed by integrating the

  6.  ADB Operations and Sector Strategy 
 
32.  Cognizant of the strong nexus between infrastructure and poverty reduction, ADB’s overall 
assistance has taken a balanced infrastructure development approach, comprising road systems, 
water transport, railways, hydrocarbons, and energy. ADB’s assistance for the energy sector as 
outlined in the 2005 country strategy and program updates9 has six main priorities: (i) reforming the 
power sector; (ii) promoting higher efficiency and low-carbon power sources (for example, run-of-
river hydropower projects and renewable energy); (iii) expanding and optimizing transmission and 
distribution systems; (iv) strengthening institutions to implement reforms required by the Electricity 
Act 2003, including the development of more flexible power delivery and trading systems; (v) 
promoting  private  sector  participation;  and  (vi)  encouraging  energy  conservation  and  ensuring 
environmental and social sustainability.

39.  Energy Efficiency Improvement and Emission Reduction. The Facility will incorporate 
state-of-the-art HVDC transmission technology. HVDC is proven to be the most cost effective 
means of transmitting bulk power over long distances, well beyond that which is feasible using 
conventional AC technology. At 1,000 MW design capacity for point-to-point transmission, HVDC is 
economically preferable for system lengths exceeding 700–800 km, and transmission losses are 
also less.   
 
40.  The proposed projects will also improve the overall power system efficiency by connecting 
1,000 MW pumped storage facilities under Project 1 and 2,600 MW hydro generation facilities

generally have only small effects on overall energy use but will focus sharply on reducing energy 
use at critical times (peak-shaving load management) and increasing off-peak energy consumption

cycled. A significant advantage of the connected pumped storage system is its ability to rapidly 
inject a large amount of power into the power grid.

B.  Technical Analysis 
 
68.  Hydropower potential in the Tehri Valley is being tapped by the development of three 
integrated power stations: the 1,000 MW Tehri-I plant, the 400 MW Koteshwar plant, and the 1,000 
MW Tehri-II pumped storage facility. In May 2006, POWERGRID commissioned the first phase of 
the transmission system associated with the power generation plants. The Tehri-I generation plant 
is under operation and Koteshwar generation plant will be operating by the end of 2008, and the 
Tehri-II pumped storage facility is planned to be commissioned by June 2011. The transmission 
capacity must be expanded in order to deliver power to Delhi and transfer beyond to various 
beneficiaries of the northern region through existing and proposed transmission lines. 
 
69.  The northeastern region, Sikkim, and Bhutan are also endowed with large hydropower 
potential. The generation addition of about 35,000 MW in the northeastern region, and 15,000 MW 
in Sikkim and Bhutan, are expected in the future. Considering the low growth of power demand in 
the northeastern region, Sikkim, and Bhutan, it is estimated that about 42,000–45,000 MW will be 
surplus in these areas, whereas the generation-addition scenarios for the northern and western

research institutions, equipment manufactures, consultants, and experts across the world, and 
concluded  that  an  ±800kV  HVDC  transmission  system  would  need  to  be  installed  and 
commissioned in stages matching with the development of hydropower generation projects in the 
northeastern region, Sikkim, and Bhutan. Further studies recommended that construction of parallel 
converters of 3,000 MW each in two stages for an ultimate capacity of 6,000 MW would be suitable 
in view of the commissioning schedule of the 2,000 MW Subansiri Lower hydropower plant by 2012 
and the 600 MW hydropower plant at Kameng by 2011. In addition, a number of power producers 
have submitted applications for transferring a total of about 4,000 MW of power by 2012 from 
Sikkim to the northern and western regions.

D.  Economic Analysis 
 
76.  Projects to be financed under the Facility will need to demonstrate economic viability and 
sustainability, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects.16 The 
inclusion of subprojects in the National Electricity Plan or other relevant least-cost transmission plan 
will be a prerequisite for funding under the MFF.   
 
77.  Economic analysis of POWERGRID’s proposed investment program under the 11th Five-
Year Plan (2008–2012) has been carried out in accordance with the Guidelines for Economic 
Analysis of Projects. A time-slice approach was adopted and the entire power sector investment 
program was considered, including upstream generation costs and downstream transmission and 
relevant distribution costs. The validity of CEA’s national electricity demand forecasts was verified 
and the least-cost nature of the proposed investment program was confirmed. The main economic 
benefits are displaced thermal electricity generation and incremental consumption. Based on the 
interregional transmission capacity that will be added through the investment program, and demand 
and generation capacity and plant factor forecasts capacity contained in the National Electricity 
Plan (Transmission), expected interregional power flows for winter, monsoon, and summer were 
modeled and used to quantify benefits. Nonincremental output displaces generation from coal-fired 
thermal plants and captive diesel plants and was valued on this basis. Incremental output was 
valued using consumers’ willingness to pay for incremental consumption. The overall investment 
program has an estimated economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of 13.1%, indicating that it is 
economically viable. Sensitivity analysis revealed that expected economic outcomes are robust 
under a range of downside scenarios, reflecting the strong link between an adequate electricity 
supply and economic growth. A summary of the economic analysis is provided in Appendix 10.

H.  Potential Risks and Assumptions 
 
87.  Key assumptions are that (i) the Government will remain committed to power sector reforms 
and development of the national electricity market, (ii) the Electricity Act 2003 will be implemented 
in a timely and transparent manner, and (iii) macroeconomic growth will remain stable. 
 
88.  Retail distribution of electricity in India is essentially handled by SEBs, and POWERGRID is 
exposed to this credit risk. While the one-time tripartite agreement settlement in 2004 resolved the 
past-due receivables and provided incentives for the improvement of current dues of the SEBs, 
there is still a residual risk, as many SEBs are still loss-making. CERC, which sets the interstate 
transmission tariffs in India, issued the most recent tariff order in 2004, to reduce POWERGRID’s 
return on equity from 16% to 14% on a post-tax basis. There may be a possibility that CERC will 
consider further reduction to lower the cost of power and augment resources of SEBs. Although 
POWERGRID’s current financial position is strong and its cash flow remains stable due to a cost-
plus  tariff  structure,  with  all  debt  servicing,  foreign  exchange  losses,  and  operation  and 
maintenance and costs allowed to be passed through, these risks may impact on its cash flow and 
implementation  of  the  investment  program.  However,  such  risks  appear  to  be  low  given 
POWERGRID’s strong financial position and stringent payment discipline for SEBs introduced in 
2003. Sensitivity analyses were conducted to estimate aggregate impact from unfavorable changes 
in key variables. Under downside scenarios, POWERGRID would maintain its financial viability to 
fully meet funding requirements of the investment program in a timely manner.  
 
89.  Other risks to the investment program include (i) delay in associated generation investments, 
(ii) increased prices of materials, and (iii) the failure to meet safeguard requirements in a timely 
manner. The investment program is properly planned and sequenced with regard to the associated 
generation  plan.  Sensitivity  analyses  of  the  investment  program  indicate  that  it  is  resilient  to 
increases  in  capital  costs  and  operation  and  maintenance  costs.  POWERGRID’s  technical 
capability to implement the investment program in a timely manner is well proven.

POWER SECTOR ASSESSMENT 
 
A.  Overview 
 
1.  Balanced infrastructure development is a major challenge to be overcome by India if it is 
to achieve its sustainable annual economic growth target of 8–9% over the next 25 years. Given 
that infrastructure inadequacies now exist in both rural and urban areas, preliminary exercises 
by the Government indicate that investment in infrastructure will need to increase from 4.6% of 
gross domestic product (GDP) to between 7% and 8% in the period of 11th Five-Year Plan 
(FY2008-FY2012). 
 
2.  Development needs in the power sector are vast. India’s need for power is growing 
rapidly, with consumption increasing by about 64% over the last 10 years. The forecast growth 
of electricity supply to support GDP growth of about 9% is expected to be 8%. This is higher 
than the last 10 years, as the energy-intensive manufacturing sector is expected to increase its 
share of GDP. However, electricity is still inaccessible to the majority of households. While over 
80% of villages are already electrified, only 44 % of total households have access to electricity, 
and in the rural areas only 33% of households have access to electricity. As of 31 March 2005, 
annual per capita electricity consumption was about 606 kilowatt-hours (kWh).  
 
3.  Energy and peaking shortage are high, with frequent load shedding (rationing) and 
significant  voltage  fluctuation  at  metered  consumer  levels.  This  undermines  industrial 
competitiveness and severely constrains economic growth. The major reasons for inadequate, 
erratic, and unreliable power supply especially at the state level are (i) inadequate power 
generation capacity, (ii) lack of optimum utilization of the existing generation capacity, (iii) an 
inadequate and aging subtransmission and distribution network, (iv) large scale theft and a 
skewed tariff structure, (v) slow pace of rural electrification, and (vi) inefficient use of electricity 
by the end consumer. 
 
4.  The total power generation capacity available to the grid was 132,329 megawatts (MW) 
as of 31 March 2007, comprising 34,653 MW of hydropower, 86,015 MW of thermal, 3,900 MW 
of nuclear, and 7,761 MW of renewable energy. State electricity boards (SEBs) own 53% of the 
total installed capacity, the central sector 34%, and the private sector 13%. From April 2006 to 
March 2007, the peak power deficit was about 13.5% (13,610 MW) and the energy deficit about 
9.9% (68,341 gigawatt-hours [GWh]).  
 
5.   In India, aggregate technical and commercial [AT&C] losses are quite high arising 
mainly  from  distribution  losses,  unmetered  connections,  theft,  and  subsidies  to  agricultural 
consumers. Nationwide AT&C losses amount to as much as 40%, compared to the world 
average of 10–15%, while some states such as Madhya Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh and Gujarat 
have shown remarkable improvement in reducing AT&C losses. The operational inefficiencies 
represented by such high AT&C losses, combined with retail tariffs set far below the cost of 
supply, have resulted in a deterioration of the financial health of state electricity boards (SEBs).. 
Despite the Government’s efforts to create enabling and encouraging policy and regulatory 
framework,  poor  creditworthiness  of  SEB  remains  a  major  hindrance  to  private  sector 
investment in some states.

B.  Legal and Regulatory Framework 
 
6.  Electric power is a concurrent matter between the central and state governments. The 
Ministry of Power (MOP) is the policy setting authority for the sector, and is assisted by the 
Central Electricity Authority (CEA) which advises central and state governments and undertakes 
planning and project appraisal. The central Government is also a major investor in the power 
sector  and  accounts  for  about  32%  of  generation  capacity.  It  operates  the  interregional 
transmission grid and is responsible for developing and funding other initiatives such as national 
power regulation, power trading, renewable energy, energy efficiency, and rural electrification. 
Private generation accounts for about 10% of supply, and all other generation, transmission, 
and distribution is supplied at the state level. 
 
7.  National  power  regulation  is  the  responsibility  of  the  Central  Electricity  Regulatory 
Commission (CERC) established in 1998. CERC has full authority to determine bulk tariffs and 
regulates  interstate,  regional,  and  interregional  transmission,  while  the  23  state  electricity 
regulatory  commissions  regulate  state  transmission  and  distribution.  State  and  central 
regulatory commissions have powers to (i) grant, amend, and revoke licenses; (ii) regulate the 
performance  of  licensees;  (iii)  determine  tariffs;  (iv)  safeguard  consumers'  interest  while 
ensuring cost recovery of electricity; (v) promote development of markets, including trading; and 
(vi) rationalize electricity tariffs by making subsidies transparent. The Appellate Tribunal for 
Electricity deals with appeals against decisions of the CERC and state electricity regulators. 
 
8.  To further accelerate the sector reforms, the Government enacted the Electricity Act 
2003, which came into force in June 2003. The Electricity Act provides for a complete legal 
framework for implementing the reforms, including the unbundling of SEBs, establishment of the 
state regulator, licensing, and an antitheft provision. The Act also represents a departure from 
the previous regime of the power sector by introducing more competition into wholesale as well 
as retail markets. Certain provisions in the Electricity Act, such as (i) open access to the 
transmission and distribution network, (ii) recognition of power trading as a distinct activity, and 
(iii) the liberal definition of a captive generating plant, are expected to introduce and encourage 
competition in the power sector. 
 
9.  Among the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) developing member countries, India has 
one of the most mature environmental regulatory systems. The system is based on command 
and  control  instruments  such  as  laws,  regulations,  and  standards.  Environmental  impact 
assessments (EIAs) for category A projects are prepared in a manner consistent with ADB’s 
environmental safeguards requirements. EIAs are required for individual power plants, and, as a 
general rule, are prepared by the project sponsors or owners. The Ministry of Environment and 
Forests (MOEF) has the final authority for EIA approval for large power plants (above 50 MW), 
and gives other environmental permits and clearances prior to construction and operations. 
State pollution control boards normally issue a  no-objection certificate for individual power 
plants, and are responsible for routine compliance oversight.1 Construction and operation of 
transmission lines and networks are considered nonpolluting. Such projects are exempt from 
the requirement to prepare and submit EIAs to MOEF, unless project works traverse forest 
areas. For these projects, an implementing agency is required to obtain forest clearance from 
MOEF.

C.  Sector Policy 
 
  1.  Medium- and Long-Term Strategy 
 
10.  Cognizant of the pivotal role that power sector development plays in economic growth 
and poverty reduction, the Government has confirmed its mission to provide electricity to all 
households at an affordable price by 2012. This goal of Power for All by 2012 has been 
elaborated into subsector-wise policies in the National Electricity Policy, which was prepared in 
February 2005 in accordance with the Electricity Act 2003. The Government has set ambitious 
energy policy objectives to achieve annual generation capacity of 1,000 kWh per capita by 
2012.  The  magnitude  of  investment  needed  to  achieve  the  goal  is  vast.  New  generation 
capacity of 78,600 MW and matching transmission and distribution facilities need to be added 
during the 11th Five-Year Plan period.  
 
11.  Integrated  Energy  Policy.  The  Integrated  Energy  Policy  (IEP)  adopted  by  the 
Government in 2006 specifies certain regulatory measures for (i) optimizing the power supply 
mix  through  greater  use  of  indigenous  hydropower  resources  and  renewable  energy,  (ii) 
pursuing technologies that maximize energy efficiency, and (iii) continuing the ongoing power 
reforms to control technical and commercial losses. The Government is attempting to turn the 
IEP targets into tangible outcomes through the provision of incentives for investors to overcome 
challenges such as (i) the perceived advantages of capital investment in everyday technology, 
(ii) smaller project sizes resulting in higher transaction costs of project preparation, and (iii) a  
lack of institutional capacities. In particular, the IEP aims to change the current hydro-thermal 
ratio of 25:75 to 40:60, with the renewable energy input to constitute not less than 10% of the 
generation base by 2012. Nationwide energy efficiency potential (including cogeneration) is 
estimated  at  over  20,000  MW,  but  the  realization  of  this  perspective  will  require  robust 
regulatory incentives on behalf of the Government.

the National Electricity Policy in February 2005 in consultation with CEA and state governments.

To achieve the overarching goal of Power for All by 2012, the National Electricity Policy aims to

14.  Coal fuel will continue to dominate power production in India in the near future, as the 
country attempts to increase its generation capacity to keep up with growing industrial and 
residential power demand. While India will continue to emphasize development of large-scale 
pithead coal-fired plants to take advantage of domestic coal resources rather than increasing 
fossil-fuel energy imports, the Government will endeavor to minimize environmental impacts 
through  employing  state-of-the-art  technologies  and  continuing  to  develop  untapped 
hydropower sources in the northeastern and northern regions.

16.  The  Government  has  initiated  several  reform  measures  to  create  a  favorable 
environment  for  addition  of  new  generating  capacity.  The  generation  of  power  no  longer

3.  Distribution Reforms 
 
18.  The major weakness of the power sector is on the distribution side which is entirely the 
domain of the states. Restructuring of state utilities is a major challenge, and the process needs 
to  safeguard  consumer  interests  while  restoring  the  financial  viability  of  the  sector. 
Consequently,  the  Accelerated  Power  Development  and  Reform  Program  (APDRP)  was 
initiated in 2001 to introduce reforms at the distribution level with an overall objective of reducing 
AT&C losses to 15% by 2007. The APDRP is an instrument to leverage distribution reforms in 
the states. Therefore, priority is given to projects from those states which have committed to a 
time-bound  program  of  reforms  including  (i)  establishment  of  a  regulator,  (ii)  filing  and 
implementation of tariff orders, (iii) securitization of dues from central public sector utilities, (iii) 
metering of 11 kV feeders, (iv) metering of all consumers, (v) energy audit at 11 kV level, and 
(vi) maintenance of grid discipline. Metering on 11 kV feeders has improved from 81% in 2001 
to 96% in 2006, and metering of consumers has improved from 78% to 92% in the same period, 
but the average AT&C losses are still close to 50%, which the Government aims to reduce to 
15% by the end of the 11th Five-Year Plan period. Functional unbundling and restructuring of 
liabilities are now mandated under the Electricity Act 2003. With financial support under the 
APDRP, many states have unbundled their SEBs to put distribution companies under regulatory 
oversight and some states have shown a much better performance than the average. The 
Government  encourages  private  sector  participation  in  distribution  and  has  privatized 
distribution companies in Orissa and Delhi. Franchising of distribution business to the private 
sector is also encouraged by the Government as a means of loss reduction and this has been 
explored in some states. 
 
4.  Private Sector Participation  
 
19.  Since the formulation of the Policy on Private Participation in the Power Sector in 1991, 
the Government has developed policy, legal, and regulatory framework to promote private 
sector participation, cognizant of the fact that the investment requirements for the power sector 
would exceed the resources available in the public sector and could not be met without private 
sector investment. The Electricity Act 2003 has opened the way for (i) competition in power 
transmission and distribution, (ii) power trading and market development, and (iii) new providers 
of power supply in rural areas.  
 
20.  In addition to the traditional independent power producer (IPP) projects, under tariff-
based competitive bidding the Government has initiated larger thermal power projects, called 
ultra mega power projects, and these use the latest super-critical boiler technologies. In the 
area of power transmission, the Government issued guidelines for private sector participation 
which envisaged two distinct options: (i) joint venture, and (ii) independent private transmission 
company. As a pilot joint venture project, Tata Power and POWERGRID are executing specific 
transmission  lines  associated  with  the  Tala  Hydro  Electric  Project  and  the  East  North

5.  Rural Electrification 
 
21.  The key development objective of the power sector is the supply of electricity to all areas 
including rural areas as mandated in Section 6 of the Electricity Act, 2003. Only about 56% of 
rural households have been electrified even though many of the households without electricity 
are willing to pay for electricity. To achieve its goal of Power for All by 2012, the Government 
initiated a new scheme called the Rajiv Gandhi Grameen Vidyutikaran Yojana in April 2005. The 
scheme aims to electrify 125,000 unelectrified villages and give access to 78 million rural 
households and is being implemented through the Rural Electrification Corporation (REC). 
Through  REC,  the  Government  provides  90%  of  the  capital  cost of  developing  (i)  a  rural 
electrification distribution backbone with at least one 33/11 kV (or 66/11 kV) substation in each 
block, (ii) village electrification infrastructure with at least one distribution transformer in each 
village or habitation, and (iii) a decentralized distributed generation system where grid supply is 
unfeasible or not cost effective.  
 
22.  The scheme also emphasizes sustainability of rural supply through collection of the cost 
of electricity from the beneficiaries. To achieve this objective, the Government encourages 
franchisees  such  as  nongovernment  organizations  and  consumer  associations.  The  state 
governments are free to provide appropriate targeted subsidies to poor households.

in 2009. As a result of its regulatory oversight, POWERGRID has been consistently profitable 
for  many  years.  Credit  Rating  Information  Services  of  India  Limited  has  assigned 
POWERGRID’s long-term bonds a local currency debt rating of AAA stable. It has not yet been 
rated by an international credit rating agency (i.e., no foreign currency issues), but the company 
is in the process of obtaining such a rating as it considers moving into foreign currency debt and 
bond markets.

outlays with 4% annual escalation. Transmission and administrative charges are projected to 
escalate at the same rate as transmission charges. Operation and maintenance expenses also 
include an expected 20% increase in employee remuneration in FY2008 (due to usual 5-year

well as interest income from bonds issued on behalf of the SEBs. Income from transmission

billing, with the balance assumed realized after 2 years.

internal cash flow and retained earnings, the remainder will be borrowed, mainly from Indian 
financial institutions and international financial institutions such as ADB and the World Bank.

loans (13-year tenors, including 3-year grace, at 9% interest), (ii) 10% through suppliers’ credits

(iii) 20% from ADB and the World Bank (20-year tenor, including 5-year grace, at 4% interest). 
The financial projections also assume a 3% exchange rate variation per annum on foreign 
currency loans, which is charged to the income statement but fully recoverable through the tariff. 
While interest rate assumptions may be low, all interest costs are an automatic pass-through in

C.  Least Cost Planning 
 
5.  At the national and regional levels, generation and transmission planning are integrated 
and  coordinated  by  CEA,  using  inputs  from  public  and  private  sector  generation  and 
transmission entities. At this level, planning is concerned with solving the objective function of 
providing electricity to points of demand at the lowest possible cost. Modeling and analysis 
takes into account and compares fuel transport costs and electricity transmission costs. In other 
words, the approach aims to determine the least cost means of supplying consumers with 
electricity.  The  National  Electricity  Plan  (Generation)  and  the  National  Electricity  Plan 
(Transmission) can therefore be considered to be least cost plans. The planning approach 
adopted by POWERGRID derives an integrated transmission plan using both top-down and 
bottom-up  inputs.  Development  of  the  transmission  plan  is  iterative;  various  input  (power 
station) scenarios and off-take (grid substation) scenarios are modeled and analyzed, with the 
ultimate intention being the identification of the lower cost means of developing the transmission 
network  under  a  reasonable  range  of  scenarios.  In  this  sense,  the  transmission  network 
development plan encapsulated in the proposed investment program is the least cost means of 
achieving a desired set of electricity transmission outcomes.

No direct impact on poverty is expected, considering that this project will strengthen the interregional grid. 
 
The sample subprojects will create significant employment opportunities for skilled and unskilled labor during their 
implementation. Unskilled labor will be employed directly for the construction of transmission lines, substations, and 
other manual works. There will also be the opportunity for employment for the post-construction phase, especially for 
maintenance. 
 
 
C.         Participation Process   
 
Is there a stake holder analysis? Yes  
 
Participation during project preparation. Since no impact and no direct beneficiaries are expected due to the 
implementation of the first tranche, nonstakeholder analysis was undertaken. Nevertheless, POWERGRID, under the 
future tranches, will undertake a full social assessment of all the stakeholders which will include consultations with 
local officials and village leaders and all the affected communities. This approach is expected to raise the level of 
awareness, build local support, and enable affected people to voice opinions and suggestions for project design and 
implementation. The poor, women, and other vulnerable groups will be carefully considered in conducting participatory 
activities. As part of the social assessment, stakeholder consultations in the project areas will be carried out with the 
broad objective of ensuring extensive participation of all types of stakeholders.  
 
Is there a participatory strategy? Yes 
 
Participation and consultation are based on a two-way information flow, from project authorities to people and from 
people to project authorities. Participation, consultation, and information dissemination will be incorporated at several 
levels during planning of subprojects under future tranches. As part of the project preparation, to ensure that 
community support is obtained and the project supports the needs of the affected persons; public consultations were 
carried out as an integral component. Continuous involvement of the stakeholders and the affected community was 
obtained. The feedback received from the consultation brought substantial inputs into the project preparation. 
Interacting with people and eliciting feedback allows affected populations to influence the decision-making process by 
raising issues that should be considered in design, mitigation, monitoring, and management plans and the analysis of 
alternatives.  The  Executing  Agency  will  ensure  that  essential  participation  focuses  will  be  adhered  to  during 
implementation. These will involve local groups in (i) preparing final compensation listings and individual claim files; (ii) 
the payment of compensation for acquired land and loss of assets and livelihood; (iii) participation in any grievance 
redress; and (iv) participation in the monitoring and evaluation process during implementation of the resettlement plan.
